3767108722.resolved_title: The True Story of Lawrence of Arabia
3767108722.excerpt: Sipping tea and chain-smoking L&M cigarettes in his reception tent in Mudowarra, Sheik Khaled Suleiman al-Atoun waves a hand to the outside, in a generally northern direction. “Lawrence came here, you know?” he says. “Several times. The biggest time was in January of 1918.

1.caption: In desert war, Lawrence advised, get to know “clans and tribes, friends and enemies, wells, hills and roads”

2.caption:
Sheik al-Atoun recalls family tales of Lawrence’s exploits. “He was an expert in demolitions,” al-Atoun says, “and taught my grandfather how it was done.” 
                        Ivor Prickett

3.caption: Capturing Aqaba was Lawrence’s great triumph: “The enemy,” he wrote, “had never imagined attack from the interior”

4.credit: Private Collection / Peter Newark Military Pictures / Bridgeman Images
4.caption: Lawrence

5.caption: After Lawrence’s crash 200 yards from his cottage

6.caption:
A swimmer finds relief from the stifling Arabian heat in the Red Sea in the coastal city of Aqaba, Jordan.  
                        Ivor Prickett

7.caption:
The only seaport of Jordan, Aqaba, on the northeastern tip of the Red Sea, is known today for its beaches and commercial activities.  
                        Ivor Prickett

8.caption:
A shopper examines produce at a market in Aqaba. Lawrence’s crucial battle for Aqaba occurred 40 miles north of the city.
                        Ivor Prickett

9.caption:
Tourists snap photos of  “Lawrence’s camp,” in Wadi Rum, which the British officer passed through during World War I.
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

10.caption:
A Bedouin man herds tourist camels across the desert through Wadi Rum, site of the Arab Revolt of 1917-18.
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

11.caption:
Storm clouds roll into the Dead Sea valley near the city of Wadi Musa. 
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

12.caption:
As a boy, Abu Enad Daraoush  and his friends found remains of Turkish forces at Aba el Lissan—“Bones everywhere,” he recalls, “skulls and ribs and spines.”  
                        Ivor Prickett

13.caption:
Storm clouds roll into the Dead Sea valley near the city of Wadi Musa. 
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

14.caption:
Once the site of bloodshed, Aba el Lissan, Jordan, saw T.E .Lawrence and his rebel fighters slaughter hundreds of Turkish soldiers in 1917.
                        Ivor Prickett

15.caption:
Writer Scott Anderson explores the crumbling ruins of southern Jordan’s Turkish forts. 
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

16.caption:
Ottoman forts and outposts have fallen to ruin in southern Jordan near the route of the old Hejaz Railway.
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

17.caption:
A window in what was once a Turkish fort overlooks a desolate desert landscape near the Hejaz Railway. 
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

19.caption:
Turkish trenches, remembrances of the war, scar the landscape in Jordan. 
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

20.caption:
A life catalogued in pictures: T.E. Lawrence’s career is captured in photographs on display in Clouds Hill. 
                        Alex Masi

21.caption:
“There is no other man I know who could have achieved what Lawrence did.” Echoing Gen. Edmund Allenby’s sentiments, pictures pay homage to the life of “Lawrence of Arabia” at Clouds Hill.
                        Alex Masi

22.caption:
Before his death, Lawrence retreated to Clouds Hill, a simple cottage in the foothills of southwest England, now open to the public.
                        Alex Masi

23.caption:
Clouds Hill holds many artifacts from Lawrence’s life, including a gramophone and a painting that once belonged to him. 
                        Alex Masi

3840287000.excerpt: While the rapid pace of developments across China’s military aerospace domain has been widely reported, the focus has typically been weighted toward fighter jets and, to a lesser extent, bombers.

1.caption: A Nanchang Q-5 Fantan attack jet prepares for takeoff in a scene typical of the PLAAF in the mid -980s, when outdated aircraft types and sheer weight of numbers were the order of the day. Sovfoto/Universal Images Group via Getty Images

3.caption: A PLAAF KJ-500 arrives at Zhuhai to take part in the Airshow China exhibition. FengJian Aviation Photos/via Chinese internet

5.caption: A preserved prototype KJ-1, based on a Soviet-made Tu-4 bomber re-engined with turboprops. Flavio Mucia/Wikimedia Commons

6.caption: A model of the AEW&C version of the Y-10 civil airliner. DZ Scan/via Chinese internet

7.caption: A Nimrod AEW3, one of a small batch of Nimrod aircraft converted to this configuration before the program was abandoned in favor of the U.S-built E-3 Sentry AWACS. Mike Freer/Wikimedia Commons

9.caption: An apparently official PLAAF photo of a KJ-2000, serial number 30571, assigned to the 26th Division. Top81/via Chinese internet

10.caption: A side view of a standard PLAAF KJ-2000, albeit with the serial number censored from the photo. FYJS/via Chinese internet

11.caption: China’s inability to procure more Il-76 airframes for conversion to KJ-2000s has provided added impetus to other AEW&C programs, namely the KJ-200 and KJ-500. Longshi/via Chinese internet

12.caption: Now used as an engine testbed, the prototype KJ-2000 is seen its maiden flight with the WS-18 turbofan in October 2014. Chinese Military Aviation/via Chinese internet

13.caption: An inflight photo of the Y-8J reveals the characteristic drooped nose radome. Longshi/via Chinese internet

14.caption: A recent photo of a PLAN Naval Aviation Y-8J, with its new low-visibility markings. via Chinese internet

15.caption: The Y-8F‑200 after being converted into a radar testbed for the ‘Balance Beam’ configuration. Top81/via Chinese internet

16.caption: A KJ-200A operated by the 26th Division, PLAAF. B747SPNKG/via Chinese internet

17.caption: A KJ-200A displays the revised nose configuration with a new and larger radome. China Aviation Photography/via Chinese internet

18.caption: A Naval Aviation KJ-200H. As evidenced by the ‘Pinocchio’ nose, these aircraft are not yet modified to KJ-200A standard. China Military/via Chinese internet

19.caption: The latest KJ-200B version. Q30/via Chinese internet

20.caption: A poor quality but rare photo apparently showing a KJ-200B in operational service. via Chinese internet

21.caption: A KJ-200A fitted with an inflight refueling probe above the cockpit is unofficially known as the KJ-200AG. Note also the ESM antennas on the rear fuselage. Longshi/via Chinese internet

22.caption: The Y-8 AEW&C rotodome testbed, serial number T0518, which appeared in early 2006. BWRY Photos/via Chinese internet

23.caption: A Pakistan Air Force ZDK-03 flies over Islamabad during rehearsals for the Pakistan Day parade in Islamabad on March 13, 2017. FAROOQ NAEEM/AFP via Getty Images

24.caption: A standard PLAAF KJ-500. China Aviation Photography/via Chinese internet

25.caption: Another view of the same KJ-500. via Chinese internet

26.caption: The probe-equipped KJ-500A is the current production variant. via Chinese internet

3896188812.given_title: In a Mutiny or Coup, the Scramble to Persuade and Pick a Side Is Critical
3896188812.resolved_title: In a Mutiny or Coup, the Scramble to Persuade and Pick a Side Is Critical
3896188812.excerpt: Coups are the ultimate fake-it-til-you-make-it endeavor. Talk to experts, and they’ll tell you that coup plotters’ most crucial task is to convince other soldiers and officers that success is assured, and that throwing their lot in with the putsch is therefore the path of prudent self-interest.

4018112357.given_title: Inside America’s Shadow War With Iran
4018112357.resolved_title: Inside America’s Shadow War With Iran
4018112357.excerpt: It’s often been said that the most dangerous hot spot in the world is the waterway between Taiwan and mainland China, where the Chinese Navy and Air Force flex their muscles every day to try to intimidate Taiwan — while the U.S. Navy patrols nearby. I wonder.

3913343065.given_title: Inside an Air Force Pararescue mission in the middle of the Pacific Ocean
3913343065.resolved_title: Inside an Air Force Pararescue mission in the middle of the Pacific Ocean
3913343065.excerpt: The text arrived on Tech Sgt. Kyle Olson’s phone late on a Friday afternoon. Olson understood immediately: somewhere in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, a 26-year-old sailor was in critical condition and the 129th Rescue Wing was going to go get him.

3773698867.given_title: Investigating the Nord Stream Pipeline Sabotage
3773698867.resolved_title: In Nord Stream Mystery, Baltic Seabed Provides a Nearly Ideal Crime Scene
3773698867.excerpt: More than 15 years ago, when the Nord Stream gas pipeline between Russia and Germany was little more than an idea, a Swedish government study warned of the risks inherent in running a critical piece of energy infrastructure along the Baltic Sea floor.

3296178340.given_title: Mahbere Dego: Clues to a Clifftop Massacre in Ethiopia
3296178340.excerpt: We used satellite imagery, 3D topographic information and social media to identify the scene of the crime. To understand why this massacre occurred where it did, it’s necessary to understand how Tigray has descended into this brutal conflict.

151337339.name:
Bellingcat Investigation Team
The Bellingcat Investigation Team is an award winning group of volunte

1.caption: A map of the Tigray Region of Ethiopia. Credit: Logan Williams / Bellingcat / Natural Earth

3862337945.given_title: One Of Rome’s Most Devastating Military Defeats Was Masterminded From Withi
3862337945.resolved_title: One Of Rome’s Most Devastating Military Defeats Was Masterminded From Within
3862337945.excerpt: In 9 AD, Rome suffered one of her most devastating military defeats – an ambush in North-Western Germany that wiped out three legions on the march, in what they believed to be pacified territory.

3858827943.given_title: Our Best Look Yet At The Massive Ordnance Penetrator Bunker Buster Bomb
3858827943.resolved_title: Our Best Look Yet At The Massive Ordnance Penetrator Bunker Buster Bomb
3858827943.excerpt: New images released by the U.S. Air Force provide what appears to be our best look yet at a live example of the service’s 30,000-pound class GBU-57/B Massive Ordnance Penetrator bunker buster, or MOP.

1.caption: MOP being moved into position. Whiteman Air Force Base via Facebook

2.caption: Whiteman Air Force Base via Facebook

3.caption: Whiteman Air Force Base via Facebook

3690658891.given_title: Russia Pulls Its ‘Syrian’ S-300 SAM Battery, Ships It To Black Sea
3690658891.resolved_title: Russia Pulls Its ‘Syrian’ S-300 SAM Battery, Ships It To Black Sea
3690658891.excerpt: Russia ‘gifted’ Syria the S-300 after a friendly fire incident, but it remained in Russia control and now it’s heading towards Ukraine.

3515853245.given_title: Russia’s Aggression Against Ukraine Is Backfiring
3515853245.resolved_title: Russia’s Aggression Against Ukraine Is Backfiring
3515853245.excerpt: Western intelligence agencies have warned that Russia is contemplating an invasion of Ukraine, perhaps involving some 175,000 troops. Vladimir Putin’s government has already moved more than 100,000 troops along Ukraine’s borders, including into Belarus.

4006801556.given_title: Russia’s shadow tanker fleet runs into trouble
4006801556.resolved_title: Russia’s shadow tanker fleet runs into trouble
4006801556.excerpt: Barring new evasive techniques by Kremlin technocrats, the rapid rise in Russia’s shadow tanker fleet since the Ukraine war may be reversing as pressure is brought to bear on India and other countries that have discreetly helped Russia beat oil and gas shipping sanctions.

1.caption: A crude oil tanker sails through ice in Russia

3707259294.given_title: Secretive B-21 bomber to be revealed to public in December - Breaking Defen
3707259294.resolved_title: Secretive B-21 bomber to be revealed to public in December
3707259294.excerpt: AFA 2022 — The US Air Force is set to lift the veil of secrecy around the B-21 Raider, its highly-classified, next-generation stealth bomber, with a formal rollout planned for the first week in December.

3810702328.given_title: Secretive military space agency stepping out of the shadows - SpaceNews
3810702328.resolved_title: Secretive military space agency stepping out of the shadows
3810702328.excerpt: When a SpaceX Falcon Heavy launched a national security mission to geostationary Earth orbit Jan. 15, the Space Force revealed that three of the payloads onboard were developed by one of its most secretive agencies, the Space Rapid Capabilities Office.

2.caption: Kelly Hammett, director and program executive officer for the Space Rapid Capabilities Office, based at Kirtland Air Force Base, New Mexico. Credit: U.S. Space Force

4002233166.given_title: The 5 best books about Special Forces — according to Green Berets
4002233166.resolved_title: The 5 best books about Special Forces — according to Green Berets
4002233166.excerpt: The U.S. Army Special Forces have established a long-standing tradition of being the go-to force for irregular warfare, no matter the environment or obstacles, earning the nickname ‘Snake Eaters’ along the way as well as the distinctive green beret.

1981343416.given_title: The American Scholar: Tales of War and Redemption - Phil Klay
1981343416.excerpt: When I was a kid, I had a comic book called The Big Book of Martyrs, part of a series by Factoid Books that included such titles as The Big Book of Thugs, The Big Book of Losers, and The Big Book of Weirdos.

3784768516.given_title: The B-21 Raider Is And Isn’t A ‘B-2 Spirit 2.0’
3784768516.resolved_title: The B-21 Raider Is And Isn’t A ‘B-2 Spirit 2.0’
3784768516.excerpt: Immediately following the glitzy rollout of the B-21 Raider at Northrop Grumman's secure facility at Plant 42 in Palmdale, California, the hot takes started piling up. "It's just an updated B-2 Spirit" and "B-2 2.0, big deal" quickly became par for the course on social media.

2379170211.given_title: The Lessons Of Dien Bien Phu | Hoover Institution
2379170211.resolved_title: The Lessons Of Dien Bien Phu
2379170211.excerpt: The most consequential military engagement in Southeast Asia in the 20th century is the 1954 Battle of Dien Bien Phu.

3816843622.given_title: The Military Adventures of Alexander the Great: An Animated Documentary Sho
3816843622.resolved_title: The Military Adventures of Alexander the Great: An Animated Documentary Shows How He Conquered Most of the Known World (336-323 BC)
3816843622.excerpt: To learn about history is to learn about war, or so it can feel when you go far back enough in time. And in any era of antiquity, few could have matched Alexander the Great’s mastery of that art.

3643583720.given_title: THE MOST DANGEROUS PLACE ON EARTH
3643583720.resolved_title: THE MOST DANGEROUS PLACE ON EARTH
3643583720.excerpt: Strolling amid the ornate 19th-century villas, fountains and lakes that dot this sleepy spa town, it’s easy to forget that you’re standing in Vladimir Putin’s crosshairs.

3938607196.excerpt: The missiles that comprise the land component of America’s nuclear triad are scattered across thousands of square miles of prairie and farmland, mainly in North Dakota, Montana, and Wyoming.

3773725660.given_title: Trapped in the Trenches in Ukraine
3773725660.resolved_title: Trapped in the Trenches in Ukraine
3773725660.excerpt: One Sunday in early October, I had lunch at an outdoor restaurant on Andriyivsky Descent, in downtown Kyiv, with a thirty-seven-year-old American who went by the code name Doc.

1.credit: Photographs  David Guttenfelder for The New Yorker
1.caption: Photographs by David Guttenfelder for The New Yorker

2.caption: Turtle approaches a rocket lodged in the road while driving to the front line in Donetsk.

3.caption: Herring, right, and T.Q., left, in the ruins of an abandoned, heavily shelled coal mine whose utility room had been converted into a makeshift command center for the 72nd Mechanized Brigade.

4.caption: Herring, braving incoming Russian artillery and tank fire, flies a reconnaissance drone while other members of his unit patrol the front line on foot.

5.caption: Soldiers take shelter in a staircase alongside a Ukrainian woman named Lena, left. She appeared to be the only remaining tenant in her building in Vuhledar, a town that no longer had electricity, heat, or running water.

6.caption: Doc, a former marine who served in Iraq and Afghanistan, decided to fight in Ukraine after leaving a job at Google.

8.caption: T.Q. enters the basement bunker where members of the unit sleep. Another fighter on the team said cheerfully that, if a Russian missile hit the house, the stockpiled ordnance would provide the mercy of an “instant death.”

11.caption: In a basement bunker in Donetsk, Tai, a New Zealander who joined the Legion unit, rests on a mattress, with a sniper rifle at his feet.

25722553.given_title: Why Arabs Lose Wars :: Middle East Quarterly
25722553.excerpt: U.S. General Norman Schwarzkopf (left) and Iraqi Lt-General Sultan Hashim Ahmed salute each other following the formal surrender of Iraq to U.S.-led coalition forces in 1991. Arabic-speaking armies have been generally ineffective in the modern era.

3741047595.given_title: Why the C-17 is the military’s flying hospital of choice
3741047595.resolved_title: Why the C-17 is the US military’s flying hospital of choice
3741047595.excerpt: One of the U.S. military’s most hard-working airplanes is the Air Force’s C-17 Globemaster III transport jet, the four-engined workhorse that can do anything from haul a tank to drop bombs.

3914024604.given_title: XQ-58 Valkyrie Solves Air Combat ‘Challenge Problem’ While Under AI Control
3914024604.resolved_title: XQ-58 Valkyrie Solves Air Combat ‘Challenge Problem’ While Under AI Control
3914024604.excerpt: One of the U.S. Air Force's stealthy XQ-58A Valkyrie drones recently completed a successful test flight demonstrating the ability to carry out aerial combat tasks autonomously using new artificial intelligence-driven software.

1.caption: An XQ-58A Valkyrie drone, at right, flies in the Eglin Test and Training Complex together with an Air Force F-15E Strike Eagle during the July 25, 2023 test. USAF

2.caption: An XQ-58A on its trailer-based launcher at Eglin Air Force Base. USAF

3.caption: An XQ-58A, at right, in formation with an F-16 Viper, during a previous test at Eglin in 2022. USAF

4.caption: A graphic with details about the platforms the US Air Force has used in its Autonomous Aircraft Experimentation
